conbody.p:
Each module should have a container topic, which provides the following:
A list of objectives for the module, using the <lcObjectives> elements: <lcObjectives> <lcObjectivesGroup> <lcObjective>Describe the kinds of topics exist in DITA</lcObjective> <lcObjective>State the information goes in different types of topics</lcObjective> <lcObjective>Give examples of constraints and specialization</lcObjective> </lcObjectivesGroup> </lcObjectives>
The objectives should state what the reader will be able to do upon completion of the module.
For a good discussion of writing objectives, see . This site makes a distinction between covert and overt objectives. An overt objective is one that can be observed or measured; these are the types of objectives you should create. Avoid creating covert objectives; they usually contains words like “understand,” “know,” and “select.”.Over time we have learned more about creating good, overt objectives. Do not look to the first few classes for exemplary objectives!
An estimated duration for the module, using the <lcDuration> element (provide a value in minutes):<lcDuration> <lcTime value="30"/> </lcDuration>
An overview of the module, using the <lcIntro> element
A list of additional reading resources, using the <related-links> element at the bottom of the topic. Be sure to code external web links with the appropriate format (usually html or pdf) and scope (external):<link href="http://www.oxygenxml.com/dita/styleguide/webhelp-feedback/#Artefact/c_Syntax_and_Markup.html" format="html" scope="external"> <linktext>DITA Style Guide, Chapter 3, Syntax and Markup</linktext> </link>
Inside the overview container, provide <learningContent> topics with the module components (lessons).
